verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to me:
verses.comment: The prophet Ezekiel receives another direct message from the LORD, indicating divine authority and inspiration for what follows. This formula often signals a new vision or prophetic oracle—see Ezekiel 22:17.

verses.text: "Son of man, there were two women, daughters of one mother.
verses.comment: The image of two sisters is a metaphor representing Samaria (northern Israel) and Jerusalem (Judah). Compare with Ezekiel 16:44-63, which uses a similar allegory.

verses.text: They acted like prostitutes in Egypt. In their youth they engaged in prostitution; there their breasts were caressed and their virgin bosoms handled.
verses.comment: References to Egypt symbolize Israel’s spiritual unfaithfulness and early idolatry—see Exodus 32:6.

verses.text: Their names were Oholah, the elder, and Oholibah, her sister. They became mine, and they bore sons and daughters. Oholah is Samaria, and Oholibah is Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The Lord claims both as His own people. Despite this, both cities betrayed Him. The marriage language hints at the covenant theme that continues into New Testament descriptions of the Church as the Bride of Christ (Ephesians 5:25-27).

verses.text: "Oholah played the prostitute while she was mine. She lusted after her lovers, after the Assyrians, warriors
verses.comment: Oholah (Samaria) sought the help of Assyria, betraying her divine covenant for political alliances, which are described in spiritual terms as prostitution.

verses.text: dressed in blue, governors and commanders, all of them desirable young men, horsemen riding on horses.
verses.comment: Assyrian military splendor drew the desire of Samaria. The symbolic description highlights the allure of worldly power in contrast to spiritual fidelity—see Genesis 3:6.

verses.text: She gave herself as a prostitute to all the elite of the Assyrians, and defiled herself with all the idols of everyone she lusted after.
verses.comment: Idolatry is linked directly to infidelity to God’s covenant. The physical and spiritual are connected here.

verses.text: She did not give up her prostitution that she had begun in Egypt; for in her youth they lay with her and caressed her virgin body and poured out their lust upon her.
verses.comment: Her continued idolatry is a sign of long-standing spiritual corruption. The explicit language emphasizes how deeply rooted the sin is.

verses.text: Therefore I handed her over to her lovers, the Assyrians, for whom she lusted.
verses.comment: God’s judgment often involves giving people over to the consequences of their chosen sins (see Romans 1:24).

verses.text: They exposed her nakedness, took away her sons and daughters, and killed her with the sword. She became a byword among women, for they executed judgment on her.
verses.comment: The Assyrian conquest resulted in the exile of Israel (Samaria) and served as a warning for others.

verses.text: "Her sister Oholibah saw this, yet she was more corrupt in her lust and prostitution than her sister.
verses.comment: Judah (Jerusalem) fails to learn from Samaria’s judgment and instead becomes even more faithless, indicating the deepening pattern of sin.

verses.text: She became even more infatuated with the Assyrians, governors and commanders, warriors dressed in splendor, horsemen riding on horses, all desirable young men.
verses.comment: Repetition reinforces Jerusalem’s idolatry and the seduction of political strength.

verses.text: I saw that she too had defiled herself; both sisters took the same path.
verses.comment: None are innocent; repeated errors lead to similar consequences. This echoes the universal call to faithfulness to God.

verses.text: But she added to her prostitution; for she saw men portrayed on a wall, images of Chaldeans portrayed in red,
verses.comment: Artistic representations of Babylonian soldiers are an object of lust, implying the power of imagery and the seduction of cultural influences.

verses.text: with belts around their waists, flowing turbans on their heads; all of them looked like officers, all of them like Babylonians, natives of Chaldea.
verses.comment: The details suggest the city was captivated by Babylonian style and culture, symbolizing fascination with worldly powers in place of loyalty to God.

verses.text: As soon as she saw them, she lusted after them and sent messengers to them in Chaldea.
verses.comment: Jerusalem actively seeks alliances with Babylon, furthering her spiritual unfaithfulness.

verses.text: Then the Babylonians came to her to bed of love and defiled her with their lust. After she was defiled by them, she turned away from them in disgust.
verses.comment: The resulting disdain after alliances suggests the emptiness of seeking fulfillment and safety outside of God’s will.

verses.text: When she exposed her prostitution and uncovered her nakedness, I turned away from her in disgust, as I had turned away from her sister.
verses.comment: God shows sorrow and righteous anger, responding as a betrayed spouse. This allegory is a strong argument for the seriousness of spiritual unfaithfulness.

verses.text: Yet she multiplied her prostitutions, remembering the days of her youth, when she prostituted herself in the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Despite many warnings, the return to old sins exposes the hardness of heart. Compare to Exodus 14:10-12 for Israel's habitual return to former ways.

verses.text: She lusted after her lovers there, whose flesh was like that of donkeys, and whose emission was like that of horses.
verses.comment: The graphic language is intended to shock, illustrating the depth of depravity accused.

verses.text: Thus you revisited the lewdness of your youth, when the Egyptians fondled your bosom and caressed your young breasts.
verses.comment: Repetition emphasizes culpability and the enduring allure of sin when not wholeheartedly rejected.

verses.text: "Therefore, Oholibah, this is what the Lord GOD says: 'I will stir up your lovers against you, from whom you turned away in disgust, and I will bring them against you from every direction:
verses.comment: Judgment is permitted through the very nations Jerusalem sought as allies. This is reminiscent of divine chastisement outlined in Deuteronomy 28:49.

verses.text: the Babylonians and all the Chaldeans, the men of Pekod, Shoa, and Koa, and all the Assyrians with them, desirable young men, governors and rulers, officers and men of renown, all of them riding on horses.
verses.comment: A complete list clarifies both superpowers—Assyria and Babylon—are appointed as agents of divine justice.

verses.text: They will come against you from the north with chariots and wagons and a great army, with shields, bucklers, and helmets. They will set themselves against you on every side. And I will give them judgment, and they shall judge you according to their own judgments.
verses.comment: Divine sovereignty ordains even the judgments of secular powers (see Romans 13:1-2 on God’s use of authorities).

verses.text: I will direct my jealousy against you, so that they may deal with you in fury. They will cut off your nose and your ears, and those of you who remain will fall by the sword. They will take your sons and daughters, and your survivors will be consumed by fire.
verses.comment: Physical mutilation echoes humbling punishments practiced in the ancient Near East. Divine jealousy is protective yet severe, paralleling Exodus 34:14: "for the LORD, whose name is Jealous, is a jealous God."

verses.text: They will also strip you of your clothes and take away your beautiful jewelry.
verses.comment: Nakedness and loss of jewelry symbolize public shame and loss of favor. Similar imagery is used for spiritual poverty in Revelation 3:17-18.

verses.text: Thus I will put an end to your lewdness and your prostitution from the land of Egypt, so that you will not lift up your eyes to them or remember Egypt anymore.
verses.comment: The goal of judgment is ultimately purification—removing all idolatrous inclinations, preparing for a faithful return to God. This foreshadows the future restoration of Jerusalem (Ezekiel 36:25-28).

verses.text: For thus says the Lord GOD: 'Behold, I will deliver you into the hands of those you hate, into the hands of those from whom you turned away in disgust.
verses.comment: God’s justice uses even the enemies of His people for correction. His goal is repentance and reconciliation.

verses.text: They will deal with you hatefully and take away all the fruit of your labor and leave you naked and bare. The shame of your prostitution will be exposed, your lewdness and promiscuity.
verses.comment: God allows the people to fully see the consequences of their actions. Spiritual nakedness is also a New Testament theme—see Revelation 16:15.

verses.text: These things will be done to you because you have acted like a prostitute after the nations and have defiled yourself with their idols.
verses.comment: Idolatry is equated with spiritual prostitution, reinforcing the seriousness of covenant faithfulness.

verses.text: "You have walked in the way of your sister; therefore I will put her cup in your hand."
verses.comment: The 'cup' often symbolizes God’s wrath—compare Jesus’s use of this image in Matthew 26:39, understanding the fullness of divine justice.

verses.text: Thus says the Lord GOD: 'You shall drink your sister’s cup, which is deep and wide. You shall be laughed at and held in derision; it holds so much.'
verses.comment: Judgment is public, as is shame, paralleling other Old Testament depictions of the 'cup of wrath.'

verses.text: You will be filled with drunkenness and sorrow, a cup of horror and devastation, the cup of your sister Samaria.
verses.comment: This further cements God’s justice as measured and appropriate. The language directly echoes the cost of separation from God.

verses.text: You shall drink it and drain it, and gnaw its shards, and tear at your breasts; for I have spoken, declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Symbolizes utter debasement. Drinking the cup until it is finished is an image later fulfilled by Christ, who drinks the cup of suffering for our reconciliation (Luke 22:42).

verses.text: Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Because you have forgotten me and cast me behind your back, you shall bear the consequences of your lewdness and prostitution."
verses.comment: Divine justice is a consequence of forgetting God—recall similar warnings in Deuteronomy 8:19.

verses.text: The LORD said to me: "Son of man, will you judge Oholah and Oholibah? Then declare to them their abominations,
verses.comment: The prophet acts as a spokesman for God’s verdict. The prophet’s role prefigures the apostolic ministry of teaching and warning the people (Matthew 28:20).

verses.text: for they have committed adultery, and blood is on their hands; with their idols they have committed adultery, and they have even offered up their sons, whom they bore to me, to them as food.
verses.comment: Child sacrifice is the height of apostasy. The seriousness of turning away from God is made clear—see Leviticus 18:21.

verses.text: Moreover, they have done this to me: on the same day they defiled my sanctuary and profaned my Sabbaths.
verses.comment: Profaning the sanctuary and Sabbath showed disregard for the solemn worship and reverence due to God. Keeping sacred practice pure is vital.

verses.text: On the very day they sacrificed their children to their idols, they entered my sanctuary and defiled it. This is what they did in my house.
verses.comment: The divine presence is abused by profane acts. Duality of worship is particularly condemned—cf. 1 Corinthians 10:21.

verses.text: "They even sent for men to come from far away, to whom a messenger was sent; and behold, they came. You bathed yourself, painted your eyes, and put on your jewelry for them.
verses.comment: Preparing to receive foreign lovers is a metaphor for making oneself available for idolatrous alliances. Similar bridal imagery can be positive or negative.

verses.text: You sat on a sumptuous couch, with a table spread before it, on which you had set my incense and my oil.
verses.comment: Resources meant for worshipping God are misused for pagan feasts, symbolizing corrupted worship.

verses.text: The noise of a carefree crowd was around her; and with men of the common sort were brought drunkards from the desert; and they put bracelets on their wrists and beautiful crowns on their heads.
verses.comment: The joyful noise is perverted, indicating false celebration. Spiritual gifts are squandered when used apart from God’s design.

verses.text: Then I said concerning her who was worn out by adultery, 'Now they will continue their adulteries with her.'
verses.comment: Even after much sin, Israel continues to seek more, displaying addiction to spiritual unfaithfulness.

verses.text: Yet they slept with her as men sleep with a prostitute; so they slept with Oholah and Oholibah, those lewd women.
verses.comment: The directness highlights the gravity of forsaking God.

verses.text: But righteous men will judge them with the judgment of adulteresses and the judgment of women who shed blood, because they are adulteresses, and blood is on their hands.
verses.comment: God delegates justice to righteous men, echoing the need for holy leaders and judgment in the community.

verses.text: "For thus says the Lord GOD: Bring up an assembly against them and give them over to terror and plunder.
verses.comment: Righteous judgment is executed through the people, showing God works both directly and through ordained authority.

verses.text: And the assembly shall stone them with stones and cut them down with their swords; they shall kill their sons and daughters and burn their houses with fire.
verses.comment: Capital punishment is implemented to purge evil—by fire and sword—reflecting the severity of God’s call to holiness.

verses.text: "Thus I will put an end to lewdness in the land, so that all women may take warning and not commit lewdness as you have done.
verses.comment: Judgment has a didactic purpose—so others may fear and turn to righteousness. This lays a foundation for future obedience and unity.

verses.text: They will repay you for your lewdness, and you will bear the penalty for your sinful idolatry. Then you will know that I am the Lord GOD."
verses.comment: The goal of discipline is restored knowledge of the Lord. This foreshadows a deeper revelation in the New Covenant, ultimately fulfilled by Christ as the one who restores the people to true worship and relationship with God (Hebrews 8:10-12).
